Your duty as a woman is to marry a man, become a housewife, act soft and feminine, and have kids. Ideally, each person should have 2.5 kids and a middle class suburban home. From nearly every pulpit these days, it is repeated day in and day out, and the message is clear. Your duty as a man is to marry a woman, go to work, have kids, and rule the home. Your duty as a woman is to marry a man, become a housewife, act soft and feminine, and have kids. Ideally, each person should have 2.5 kids and a middle class suburban home. Single people are looked down on and shamed. Even within married couples, people who don't or can't have kids, don't strictly follow traditional gender roles, marry interracially, don't blindly support everything certain political figures do, etc. are not welcomed. And if your family has a bad reputation, you do too, because badness runs in families apparently. And biological family is always more important than everyone else, including even adopted children. And the stereotypical 1950s family is obviously the core tenant of the Christian faith, and even the slightest deviation from this ideal is the devil. Never mind the fact that Jesus praised people who didn't marry and taught people to leave their "family values" behind to follow him. He must just be a demonic agent sent to destroy the nuclear family!

This is a serious problem. It's gotten to the point where many of you talk about literally nothing else. People who choose not to marry are sinning, is how it gets treated, and so severely that it needs to be fought against every chance you get. As if the sole purpose of life is to marry and have kids, and anyone who doesn't do that, exactly the way it would look on a 50s show, is neglecting their biggest duty and committing an unforgivable sin. Not marrying and having kids is simply unacceptable many say, *especially* if you're a woman, but often men too.

Is there a particular reason why this is such a huge deal now? What exactly is wrong with someone whose calling is not marrying and creating a stereotypical family?
